=Tutorial: FIELDLINES NCSX Tutorial[[image:ncsx_fieldlines.jpg width="240" height="172" align="right"]]= 
<span style="background-color: #ffffff;">This tutorial will walk the user through running the FIELDLINES code for a VMEC NCSX equilibrium.</span>

----

# __**Edit the input namelist text file.**__
> <span style="background-color: #ffffff;">The input namelist (input.ncsx_c09r00_free) will need to be modified for the </span><span style="background-color: #ffffff;">[[vmecwiki/FIELDLINES|FIELDLINES]]</span><span style="background-color: #ffffff;"> code. The </span><span style="background-color: #ffffff;">[[vmecwiki/FIELDLINES|FIELDLINES]]</span><span style="background-color: #ffffff;"> code utilizes the EXTCUR array from the </span><span style="background-color: #ffffff;">[[vmecwiki/VMEC|VMEC]]</span><span style="background-color: #ffffff;"> INDATA namelist and reads it's own FIELDLINES_INPUT namelist from this file. For other codes (</span><span style="background-color: #ffffff;">[[vmecwiki/PIES|PIES]]</span><span style="background-color: #ffffff;">/</span><span style="background-color: #ffffff;">[[vmecwiki/SPEC|SPEC]]</span><span style="background-color: #ffffff;">) the namelist should be added to the corresponding input file. Since we will be including the VMEC plasma and plasma response, we will need the VMEC wout file to be located in the same directory. The namelist should look like the following:</span>
> [[code format="fortran"]]
 &INDATA
 .
 .
 .
 EXTCUR =   6.52271941985300E+05  6.51868569367400E+05  5.37743588647300E+05
 2.50000000000000E-07  2.50000000000000E-07  2.80949750000000E+04
 -5.48049500000000E+04  3.01228950000000E+04  9.42409100000000E+04
 4.55138737653200E+04
 .
 .
 .
 /
 &FIELDLINES_INPUT
  NR = 201
  NZ = 201
  NPHI = 60
  RMIN = 0.436
  RMAX = 2.436
  ZMIN = -1.0
  ZMAX = 1.0
  PHIMIN = 0.0
  PHIMAX = 2.09439510239
  MU = 0.0
  R_START =  1.6078237350E+00    1.6100000000E+00    1.6200000000E+00    1.6300000000E+00
    1.6400000000E+00    1.6500000000E+00    1.6600000000E+00    1.6700000000E+00
    1.6800000000E+00    1.6900000000E+00    1.7000000000E+00    1.7100000000E+00
    1.7200000000E+00    1.7300000000E+00    1.7400000000E+00    1.7500000000E+00
    1.7510000000E+00    1.7520000000E+00    1.7530000000E+00    1.7540000000E+00
    1.7550000000E+00    1.7560000000E+00    1.7570000000E+00    1.7580000000E+00
    1.7590000000E+00    1.7600000000E+00    1.7610000000E+00
 Z_START = 26*0.00  
 PHI_START = 26*0.00
 PHI_END   = 26*6283.0
 NPOINC    = 120
 INT_TYPE  = 'NAG'
 FOLLOW_TOL = 1.0E-9
 VC_ADAPT_TOL = 1.0E-4
 &END 
[[code]]
> <span style="background-color: #ffffff;">This will follow 40 field lines for ~1000 toroidal transits. The NPOINC parameter indicates that we wish to save the location of the field lines 120 times per field period (approximately every degree in phi). The code will use the NAG routines for following field lines. If the user does not have access to the NAG libraries, they should replace NAG with LSODE and use the Livermore solver.</span>
> 
# __**Execute the code.**__
> <span style="background-color: #ffffff;">We execute the code by providing the type of equilibria followed by the input file extension. Vacuum fields can either be specified by coil or mgrid, here we've utilized our mgrid file.</span>
> [[code format="bash"]]
>~/bin_847/xfieldlines -vmec ncsx_c09r00_free -mgrid mgrid_c09r00.nc
FIELDLINES Version 1.00
----- Input Parameters -----
   FILE: input.ncsx_c09r00_free
   R   = [ 0.43600, 2.43600];  NR:    201
   PHI = [ 0.00000, 2.09440];  NPHI:   60
   Z   = [-1.00000, 1.00000];  NZ:    201
   # of Fieldlines:   27
----- MGRID Information -----
   FILE:mgrid_c09r00.nc
   R   = [ 0.43600, 2.43600];  NR   =  201
   PHI = [ 0.00000, 2.09440];  NPHI =   37
   Z   = [-1.00000, 1.00000];  NZ   =  201
----- Virtual Casing Information -----
   MIN_GRID_DISTANCE = 8.9562E-02
   NU =   89;  NV =   60;  NFP =   3
   NUVP =  16020
----- Constructing Splines -----      
   R   = [ 0.43600, 2.43600];  NR:    201
   PHI = [ 0.00000, 2.09440];  NPHI:   60

   HERMITE FORM: 1
----- FOLLOWING FIELD LINES -----

----- FIELDLINES DONE -----
>
[[code]]
> <span style="background-color: #ffffff;">The code outputs an HDF5 file with the fieldline data and grid as the contents. Note that the code is parallelized, so when running the code on parallel machines, the mpirun command must be used.</span>
> 
# __**Examine the output.**__
> <span style="background-color: #ffffff;">The output of the </span><span style="background-color: #ffffff;">[[vmecwiki/FIELDLINES|FIELDLINES]]</span><span style="background-color: #ffffff;"> code is stored in an HDF5 file called fieldlines_ext.h5 where ext is the input extension of the input file. The field line data is saved NPOINC steps per field period. To construct a Poincar√© plot the user must simply chose the index of the cross section they'd like and step by NPOINC indexes to find the next point. This assumes the user started all field lines from the same phi plane. Additionally, the grid and field (B_R/B_PHI and B_Z/B_PHI) are stored in the file, this is done to aide in restarts.</span>
